awd_titl_txt: CAREER: A Multi-scale Methodology for Assessing the Reductions in Seismic Risk Possible through Building Retrofit Design and Policy, from Buildings to Communities
awd_abstract_narration:
The research objective of this Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) program award is to develop multi-scale models to evaluate the impacts of retrofit design and policy on a community for earthquake risk reduction. The emphasis on retrofit is motivated by the large number of older buildings that predate major changes to seismic code provisions and, as a result, are vulnerable to earthquake-induced damage. To date, progress in retrofitting these buildings has been slow to significantly reduce risk of damage, in part because building owners find retrofit costs are expensive in competitive market. This research addresses the problem of seismic retrofit at three levels of analysis: individual buildings, communities, and policy choices. The study will begin by developing a probabilistic methodology for classifying and characterizing retrofitted structures for the purpose of systematically assessing the fragility of retrofitted buildings and the reduction in seismic risk. These evaluations will be combined, using advanced methods to quantify correlations and interdependencies in structural response, to produce community-scale assessments of seismic risk. The research will also model the influence of retrofit policies on community seismic risk reduction, incorporating historical data on policy implementation. 

The outcome of this research will be a framework for evaluating seismic retrofit and other potential mitigation alternatives through integrated assessment of structural response and community impacts. The methodology lays the groundwork for a re-evaluation not only of seismic retrofit and policy making, but also mitigation activities to reduce risks from other hazards. The integrated education plans will lead to the development of new service-learning course modules. In these modules, students will partner with Colorado-based non-profit organizations that help needy individuals and organizations build and improve homes or other facilities. These service learning modules are a vehicle to improve practical learning about structural analysis, design and retrofit, to improve retention of diverse and motivated students in structural engineering, and to prepare students to be leading practitioners in dealing with vulnerable existing buildings. Curriculum materials developed for service learning will be made available to other faculty and universities.

por.por_cntn:
This Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) program award aimed to evaluate the impacts of seismic retrofit design and policy on a community in terms of earthquake risk reduction. The emphasis on retrofit was motivated by the large number of older buildings that predate major changes to seismic code provisions and, as a result, are vulnerable to earthquake-induced damage. Progress in retrofitting these buildings has been slow to significantly reduce risk of damage, in part because building owners find retrofit costs are expensive. However, an increasing number of jurisdictions are incentivizing or mandating retrofit through various strategies, and more information is needed about how these policies can be most effective.

 

This project addressed the problem of seismic retrofit of nonductile reinforced concrete moment frame buildings at three levels of analysis: individual buildings, communities, and policy choices. For individual buildings, the results showed that aggressive retrofits, like those targeting “Immediate Occupancy” performance goals, generally perform as expected, with buildings retaining nearly all their strength and stiffness after design level shaking events, and avoiding column damage. However, improvements in nonstructural performance may not be significant without design efforts specifically targeting those components. For retrofits designed less aggressively, the performance of the retrofitted structures is better than the unretrofit structures, but highly variable. These results also showed that increases to strength and stiffness are needed to avoid earthquake-induced repairs and economic losses. Collapse safety can be improved by increasing strength or deformation capacity; as a result, some retrofits can significantly improve collapse risk without reducing economic losses. For communities, the results show that retrofit policies could address as few as 60% of the potentially vulnerable buildings if the most vulnerable buildings were identified,  and the retrofits met “Immediate Occupancy” requirements. On the other hand, to meet community objectives of seismic performance, a larger number of buildings needs to be retrofit if the retrofit designs are not as effective.  These results show that a community perspective on retrofit goals may motivate different actions than a building-by-building perspective. The study also developed an online database to compare municipal retrofit ordinances from a policy perspective.

 

The integrated education plans led to the development of new service-learning course modules.  These modules brought nearly 200 students from the University of Colorado to work on building energy-efficient, affordable homes for families in the Boulder Valley, integrating their hands-on construction work with engineering risk assessment and statistics.  A particular focus was working with an organization rebuilding homes after the 2013 Boulder floods. The module had a number of positive outcomes, including engagement of a high percentage of (underrepresented) women students from the class, improving students understanding of disasters/flood risk, real world engineering and construction projects, and fostering a sense of community both within the class and the broader community. Student feedback on the workday, as well as the associated reflection and reports, was very positive. Curriculum materials developed for the service learning are available online.
